articles.headline: Bell Pottinger, British P.R. Firm for Questionable Clients, Collapses
articles.snippet: The firm’s financial failure was hastened by a race-baiting campaign it undertook in South Africa that spiraled into a disaster.
articles.abstract: The firm’s financial failure was hastened by a race-baiting campaign it undertook in South Africa that spiraled into a disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the South African track star Oscar Pistorius stood trial for the brutal killing of his girlfriend, he hired Bell Pottinger, an aggressive British public relations firm, to try to smooth his tattered reputation. President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his wife turned to the firm for help in recasting their image. So did Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the dictator of Belarus.

articles.headline: Edith Windsor, Whose Same-Sex Marriage Fight Led to Landmark Ruling, Dies at 88
articles.snippet: Ms. Windsor’s case struck down the Defense of Marriage Act in 2013 and granted same-sex married couples federal recognition for the first time.
articles.abstract: Ms. Windsor’s case struck down the Defense of Marriage Act in 2013 and granted same-sex married couples federal recognition for the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edith Windsor, the gay-rights activist whose landmark case led the Supreme Court to grant same-sex married couples federal recognition for the first time and rights to a host of federal benefits that until then only married heterosexuals had enjoyed, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 88.

articles.headline: Amid Chaos of Storms, U.S. Shows It Has Improved Its Response
articles.snippet: Technology, building codes, weather forecasts and a more sophisticated understanding of mass evacuation helped keep the death toll low, experts say.
articles.abstract: Technology, building codes, weather forecasts and a more sophisticated understanding of mass evacuation helped keep the death toll low, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The two massive storms brought death and suffering and damage that will be measured in the billions of dollars. They left millions of residents cowering in their homes to ride out pounding rains, and left evacuees — hundreds of thousands of them — scattered across Texas and the Southeast.

articles.headline: ‘It Was a Frat House’: Inside the Sex Scandal That Toppled SoFi’s C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Mike Cagney is stepping down as chief executive of the lending start-up Social Finance amid questions about sexual harassment at the company. Inside the events that preceded the move.
articles.abstract: Mike Cagney is stepping down as chief executive of the lending start-up Social Finance amid questions about sexual harassment at the company. Inside the events that preceded the move.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, the text messages came. Some were flirtatious, asking her to meet him late at night. Sometimes, the texts were sexually explicit.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Katie Benner

articles.headline: White House Weighs Lowering Refugee Quota to Below 50,000
articles.snippet: The issue has ignited intense debate within the administration, with officials at the National Security Council, the State Department and the Department of Defense opposing a precipitous drop.
articles.abstract: The issue has ignited intense debate within the administration, with officials at the National Security Council, the State Department and the Department of Defense opposing a precipitous drop.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering reducing the number of refugees admitted to the country over the next year to below 50,000, according to current and former government officials familiar with the discussions, the lowest number since at least 1980.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Miriam Jordan

articles.headline: In China’s Hinterlands, Workers Mine Bitcoin for a Digital Fortune
articles.snippet: One of the largest sources of Bitcoin can be found in the grasslands of Inner Mongolia, despite Chinese skepticism over its potential for risk.
articles.abstract: One of the largest sources of Bitcoin can be found in the grasslands of Inner Mongolia, despite Chinese skepticism over its potential for risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALAD BANNER, China — They worked as factory hands, in the coal business and as farmers. Their spirits rose when a coal boom promised to bring factories and jobs to this land of grassy plains in Inner Mongolia. When the boom ebbed, they looked for work wherever they could.
articles.byline: By Cao Li and Giulia Marchi

articles.headline: As German Election Looms, Politicians Face Voters’ Wrath for Ties to Carmakers
articles.snippet: A diesel emissions crisis has put the spotlight on links between the auto industry — responsible for Germany’s most important export — and the country’s leaders.
articles.abstract: A diesel emissions crisis has put the spotlight on links between the auto industry — responsible for Germany’s most important export — and the country’s leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Sometimes it is hard to tell where the German government ends and the auto industry begins.

articles.headline: Eight Dead From Sweltering Nursing Home as Florida Struggles After Irma
articles.snippet: A criminal investigation was opened into a nursing home where eight died after the air-conditioning failed, a situation the governor called “unfathomable.”
articles.abstract: A criminal investigation was opened into a nursing home where eight died after the air-conditioning failed, a situation the governor called “unfathomable.”
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The first patient was rushed into the emergency room of Memorial Regional Hospital around 3 a.m. on Wednesday, escaping a nursing home that had lost air-conditioning in the muggy days after Hurricane Irma splintered power lines across the state.
articles.byline: By Neil Reisner, Sheri Fink and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Trump Goes All In on a Tax Overhaul Whose Details Remain Unwritten
articles.snippet: President Trump has been wooing Democrats and pressing Republicans for fast action on a rewrite of the tax code, but huge hurdles remain.
articles.abstract: President Trump has been wooing Democrats and pressing Republicans for fast action on a rewrite of the tax code, but huge hurdles remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is doubling down this week on his bid to remake the tax code, meeting with Democrats, tying tax legislation to hurricane recovery and dispatching his economic team to Capitol Hill almost daily to prod lawmakers into action.
